Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: In response to global declines in fisheries products and degradation of marine ecosystems, the tropical ornamental mariculture industry has shown rapid growth. To meet the demand for highly skilled technical labor and to stimulate the further development of a tropical ornamental mariculture industry in Florida, Florida Keys Community College (FKCC) proposes the development of a Tropical Ornamental Mariculture Technician (TOMT) certificate. The certificate requires completion of 27 credit hours of in class course work, laboratory and field studies. The capstone course for the certificate is an internship at one of four tropical ornamental mariculture facilities in the Florida Keys (South Eastern Aquatechnologies, Inc., The Coral Restoration Foundation, Mote Tropical Research Laboratory, and Atlantic Reef Aquaculture) working with research and production of marine ornamental aquaculture organisms. The proposed Tropical Ornamental Mariculture Technician Certificate will provide a needed educational platform for the development of well-prepared technicians necessary for growth and development of the marine ornamental mariculture industry and marine conservation efforts during the 21st century. The proposal team is composed of experts in the fields of Marine Biology, Fisheries Science, Biological Oceanography (emphasis on Marine Community Ecology & Fishery Management), Aquaculture and Veterinary sciences. In addition to scientific knowledge, graduates will gain a thorough knowledge of the business environment associated with the aquaculture industry. The types of modular tropical ornamental mariculture systems employed during the proposed project are ideally suited to small business development and, therefore, may have substantial impacts on the local and regional economies.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Aquaculture is the fastest growing sector of the global food producing industries and as the industry expands into the ocean (i.e. marine aquaculture or mariculture), it has extraordinary potential for supplying the current and future demand for seafood resources. Therefore, marine aquaculture promises to be a major workforce employer for marine scientist during the 21st century and beyond. Moreover, the demand for marine ornamental species for the aquarium trade often relies on environmentally harmful wild capture techniques for these valuable marine organisms. Therefore, in order to provide an instructional model  to train the workforce needed to meet the current and future demands for the this burgeoning industry, and provide technology and skills that can help reduce the demand for wild captured marine organisms for the marine aquarium trade, Florida Keys Community College (FKCC) with assistance from the National Science Foundation (NSF) developed a unique technician-level marine aquaculture training program entitled the Tropical Ornamental Mariculture Technician (TOMT) certificate.     

 

By far the greatest project outcome for the TOMT certificate is the development of a very successful, self-sustaining academic program that engages students in science and technology using marine aquaculture and undergraduate research as educational tools. The NSF funding has allowed the TOMT program to develop a world class marine aquaculture team that uses groundbreaking applied research to engage students in science and technology. Research topics include: (1) developing alternative live-food production technology (e.g., white worms and copepod collection systems), (2) developing spawning and larval rearing protocols for new, high demand marine ornamental species, and (3) research and development of more efficient larval rearing systems to: (i) reduce problems associated with current marine larval rearing protocols (e.g. cannibalism, disease, growth, etc.) and (ii) increase larval survival rates.

 

The program has developed state-of-the-technology marine aquaculture systems devoted to hands-on educational training. These systems allow students to work directly with live organisms to develop unique skills and learn specific techniques associated with marine aquaculture. The outdoor aquaculture systems (Fig. 1), which utilize the pristine tropical water of the Florida Keys, are devoted to local marine ornamental species [Fig.2 A) – C)].

 

The indoor aquaculture systems (Fig. 3) utilize closed recirculating systems that allow students to work with non-native model marine ornamental species like clownfish and dottybacks (Fig. 4).

 

The TOMT lab has become a bustling hub for TOMT students, interns, volunteers, and aquarium enthusiasts. The TOMT program has partnered with FKCC’s Project ACCESS (Accessing Community College Educational experiences, Social experiences and Skills for careers) program - a comprehensive transition and post-secondary program designed to support students with intellectual disabilities - to provide guided internships in our aquaculture laboratory. Many of the certificate graduates continue their education at FKCC in the Associate of Science degree for Marine Environmental Technology. In addition, the program has produced: (1) graduates that are now working in the marine science and aquaculture industries, (2) student presentations at national meetings (e.g. NSF Advanced Technology Education Principal Investigator Conference and the World Aquaculture Society’s Aquaculture America), (3) a student marine aquaculture club with a social media presence and (4) hundreds of marine ornamental organisms including orchid dottybacks, several marine invertebrates, and three species of clownfish, including the species known as “N...

The outdoor aquaculture systems (Fig. 1), which utilize the pristine tropical water of the Florida Keys, are devoted to local marine ornamental species [Fig.2 A) – C)]. The TOMT lab has become a bustling hub for TOMT students, interns, volunteers, and aquarium enthusiasts. The TOMT program has partnered with FKCCÆs Project ACCESS (Accessing Community College Educational experiences, Social experiences and Skills for careers) program - a comprehensive transition and post-secondary program designed to support students with intellectual disabilities - to provide guided internships in our aquaculture laboratory. Many of the certificate graduates continue their education at FKCC in the Associate of Science degree for Marine Environmental Technology. In addition, the program has produced: (1) graduates that are now working in the marine science and aquaculture industries, (2) student presentations at national meetings (e.g. NSF Advanced Technology Education Principal Investigator Conference and the World Aquaculture SocietyÆs Aquaculture America), (3) a student marine aquaculture club with a social media presence and (4) hundreds of marine ornamental organisms including orchid dottybacks, several marine invertebrates, and three species of clownfish, including the species known as "Nemo" (Fig. 5).
